subject: history
title: Khilafat Movement (1919-1924)
description: Muslim movement for Turkish Caliph; Gandhi's Hindu-Muslim unity strategy

definition: Caliph = Khalifa = Successor of Prophet Muhammad
Spiritual and temporal leader of Sunni Muslims worldwide
Ottoman Sultan of Turkey held Caliphate since 1517
significance: For Indian Muslims: Turkish Sultan was Caliph (Amir-ul-Momineen)
Not direct political authority but spiritual leadership
details.reality: By 20th century, Caliph's actual power minimal; mostly symbolic; but emotionally important for Muslims

war: Ottoman Turkey sided with Germany (Central Powers)
Indian Muslims conflicted: loyal to British Empire but Turkey had Caliph
British propaganda said war not against Caliph/Islam
Muslims fought for Britain despite Turkey being enemy
promise: British promised not to harm Caliph or dismember Turkey
Lloyd George (British PM) promised in 1918: Turkey not to be deprived of rich and renowned lands of Asia Minor and Thrace
Indian Muslims fought loyally based on these promises

defeat: Allied Powers (Britain, France, Italy) occupied Turkey
details.treatyOfSevres: Treaty of S√®vres (August 10, 1920): Ottoman Empire dismembered; Turkey reduced to small area in Anatolia; Holy places (Mecca, Medina, Jerusalem) taken away; European powers controlled Turkish territories; Caliph's authority reduced to nothing
muslimAngre: Saw it as attack on Islam

formation: Leaders: Ali Brothers (Maulana Mohammad Ali, Maulana Shaukat Ali), Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Hakim Ajmal Khan, Hasrat Mohani
demands: Control of holy places to Caliph
methods: Initially: Constitutional methods - petitions, memorials, delegations

gandhiMotivation: Gandhi saw Khilafat as opportunity for Hindu-Muslim unity
Muslims aggrieved over Khilafat; Hindus over Rowlatt-Jallianwala
Combined grievances could create powerful mass movement
Believed supporting Muslims in just cause was religious duty (Hindu dharma)
strategy: Became President of All-India Khilafat Committee
Advised Muslims to adopt non-violent non-cooperation
Linked Khilafat with Punjab wrongs (Jallianwala Bagh) and Swaraj
gandhiLogic: 'Wrongs done to Punjab and Khilafat are not separate issues'
'Supporting Muslims in their religious cause will unite Hindus and Muslims'
'Swaraj in one year if unity maintained'

details.mohammadAli: **Maulana Mohammad Ali Jauhar**: Educated at Oxford; journalist; edited 'Comrade' and 'Hamdard'; Most prominent Khilafat leader; fiery orator; Imprisoned 1915-1919 for pro-Turkey views during WWI
details.shaukatAli: **Maulana Shaukat Ali**: Brother of Mohammad Ali; equally committed to cause; Worked closely with Gandhi
characteristics: Partnership with Gandhi exemplified Hindu-Muslim unity

decisions: Threatened non-cooperation if demands not met
Collected funds ('Tilak Swaraj Fund' merged with Khilafat Fund)
details.significance: First major joint Hindu-Muslim political conference
Showed potential of united Hindu-Muslim action

mission: Delegation led by Mohammad Ali went to England (March 1920)
Demanded justice for Turkey and Caliph
Met British leaders including Prime Minister
British refused to change policy on Turkey

categories.label: Merger with Non-Cooperation Movement
categories.description: Khilafat merged with wider freedom struggle

decision: Khilafat issue included along with Punjab wrongs
details.opposition: Some Congress moderates opposed; C.R. Das, Lajpat Rai had reservations; but Gandhi prevailed

confirmation: Congress goal changed from self-government within Empire to Swaraj (complete self-rule)
details.unity: Peak of Hindu-Muslim cooperation; Ali Brothers and Gandhi toured together

characteristics: Gandhi and Ali Brothers held joint rallies
Khilafat volunteers and Congress volunteers worked together
activities: Boycott of British goods, institutions, titles
details.scale: Largest mass movement till then; millions participated

incident: Mob burned police station; 22 policemen killed
impact: Some felt Gandhi abandoned them midway

kemalRevolution: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk led Turkish nationalist revolution
Treaty of Lausanne (1923) replaced Treaty of S√®vres
abolition: Turkish Grand National Assembly abolished Sultanate (Nov 1, 1922)
irony: Indians fighting for Caliphate; Turks themselves abolished it
Turks chose nationalism over religious institution
Indian Muslims had no more cause to fight

breakdown: After 1922, Hindu-Muslim unity broke down rapidly
Moplah Rebellion (1921) in Kerala had communal overtones
reasons: Khilafat issue dead; no common cause
Extremist elements on both sides grew
Economic competition for jobs and resources
Cow slaughter and music-before-mosque issues flared up
aftermath: Hindu Mahasabha and Muslim League became more aggressive
Path toward communalism and eventual Partition
Golden period of unity (1920-22) proved short-lived

differences: Ali Brothers felt Gandhi betrayed them by calling off movement
Mohammad Ali later joined Muslim League
details.mohammadAliDeath: Died 1931 in London; buried in Jerusalem (as per wish, not to be buried under British India)
details.legacy: Brief unity period remembered nostalgically; but couldn't be sustained

assessment.title: Assessment of Khilafat Movement
achievements: Brought Muslims into mainstream nationalist movement
Made Congress truly all-India and multi-religious
Showed potential of non-violent mass struggle
failures: Based on religious issue, not secular nationalism
When Khilafat issue died, unity collapsed
Led to communalism and eventual Partition
Gandhi's religious appeal had unintended consequences

critics: Some say Gandhi wrong to bring religion into politics
Communalized politics by supporting religious cause
Short-term unity at cost of long-term communalism
defenders: Gandhi had noble intention: supporting Muslims in just cause
Unity was genuine even if temporary
Showed what could be achieved with cooperation
Blame should go to British divide-and-rule, not Gandhi

historicalSignificance: Peak of Hindu-Muslim cooperation in freedom struggle
Lesson: religious issues make poor foundation for political unity
Path to Partition can be traced partly to Khilafat aftermath

mustRemember: Khilafat = Movement to restore authority of Turkish Caliph
Post-WWI: Treaty of S√®vres (1920) humiliated Turkey and Caliph
Leaders: Ali Brothers (Mohammad Ali, Shaukat Ali), Maulana Azad
Gandhi joined to create Hindu-Muslim unity
Ended when Turkey itself abolished Caliphate (March 3, 1924)
Also ended due to Chauri Chaura (Gandhi called off NCM)
